awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Dimers in Combinatorics and Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Statistical mechanics is the mathematical study of matter at small scales.  Its primary goals are to analyze phase transitions: for example liquid-to-solid transitions where the physical properties of a substance change abruptly.  The dimer model was originally conceived as a simplified model of two-dimensional matter in which phase transitions can be studied. Recent work, however, has linked the model to many other areas of mathematics, from combinatorics to string theory, where ''brane dimers'' are proposed as fundamental descriptions of spacetime at small scales.  The PIs propose to jointly investigate a number of interrelated topics in mathematics and physics, each of which has the dimer model as its underlying combinatorial structure. This project will lead to the organization of workshops and regular meetings of the PIs and their graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, continuing the PIs' efforts to get young mathematicians and physicists involved in these topics.  The PIs will contribute to the mathematical community through their mentorship of young scholars, research talks in conferences and workshops, papers published in peer-reviewed journals, and books on a selection of these topics.

The dimer model studies the set of all dimers, or perfect matchings, on a planar bipartite graph G on a disk or Riemann surface. Despite the simple definition, there are many open problems about the dimer model, as well as applications to geometry, algebra, and physics. There is a fundamental connection between the dimer model on the disk and the Grassmannian, via the fact that generating functions of dimers satisfy Plucker relations. This fact leads to the cluster algebra structure on the homogeneous coordinate ring of the Grassmannian, and the beautiful combinatorics of the positive Grassmannian.  This project will explore a myriad of generalizations of the objects mentioned above, and will significantly improve our understanding of: the dimer model on non-planar graphs; limiting behaviors of the dimer model on a torus and other surfaces; the connection between dimers on a torus and brane tilings in string theory; soliton solutions to the KP equation and the bipartite graphs realizable as soliton graphs; the relationship between convex polygon tilings and the corresponding bipartite planar graphs with Kasteleyn weightings; the connection between the dimer model and triangulations of the amplituhedron, an object whose volume computes scattering amplitudes; and higher-dimensional dimer models, colored quivers and a generalized notion of cluster mutation, exciting new objects motivated by dualities in supersymmetric quantum field theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit 

 

Dimer models were originally conceived as simplified statistical mechanical models for the study of phase transitions. In recent years, applications their applications have blossomed, ranging from combinatorics and cluster algebra in mathematics to quantum field theory and string theory in physics. The primary goal of this proposal was to investigate various applications and generalizations of dimer models at the Math/Physics interface. This project led to significant progress on multiple fronts, in collaboration with various colleagues, including:

 - Franco studied the m-graded quiver theories associated to Calabi-Yau (CY) (m+2)-folds and classified the webs of theories connected by dualities that they form using Diophantine Equations. These theories are described by higher dimensional generalizations of dimer.

- He introduced a new algorithm, which denoted Calabi-Yau product, that determines the generalized dimer model of a higher dimensional CY in terms of the ones for two lower dimensional CYs. The new method allows the determination of models for geometries that were previously out of practical reach.

- He initiated the study of applications of machine learning to Seiberg duality, focusing on the case of quiver gauge theories, a problem also of interest in the context of dimer models and cluster algebras.

- He developed new tools based on dimer models to engineer 4d quantum field theories on D3-branes on orientifolds of toric CY 3-folds. He then used these tools to construct the first model of this type in String Theory leading to dynamical supersymmetry breaking and without any known instability.

- He introduced 3d generalizations of dimer models associated to two-dimensional CW complexes on 3-manifolds. This family of models defines a new class of 2d quantum field theories with remarkable combinatorial properties, which generalize dimer models, and connections to toric geometry.

- He introduced and studied a new type of orientifold quotients of brane brick models by antiholomorphic involutions leading to 2d N=(0,1) gauge theories. This line of investigation significantly extends this class of generalized dimer models and provides a string theory realization of 2d quantum field theories with minimal supersymmetry.

- He applied ideas originating from quiver gauge theories and dimer models to the study of fractons, a new class of models that have received significant attention in condensed matter physics.

- He constructed the Brane Brick Models associated to the 18 regular reflexive polytopes corresponding to smooth Fano 3-folds. This is the first construction of the corresponding 2d quantum field theories.

- He applied techniques developed by him and collaborators in previous years (such as orbifold reduction and 3d printing) to generate the Brane Brick Models for infinite families of CY 4-folds with known metrics. Furthermore, he investigated the correspondence between geometry and gauge theory in this context.

- He worked out the map between mass deformations of brane brick models and the corresponding deformations of toric CY 4-folds.

- He initiated a program aimed at understanding the geometry and 5d quantum field theories associated to Generalized Toric Polygons (GTPs). As part of this program, He introduced the concept of Twin Quivers and relates its mutations to polytope mutations.

- He introduced and studied a class of statistical models of crystal melting based on Brane Brick Models that count the BPS bound states of branes on toric Calabi-Yau 4-folds.

- Generalized global symmetries, in particular non-invertible and categorical symmetries, have become a focal point in the recent study of quantum field theory. He studied the symmetry topological field theories and anomalies of non-invertible symmetries for 2D QFTs from a string theory using Brane Brick Models.

 

Broader Impacts

Franco continued running an energetic STEM outreach program with the CCNY Physics Club, in partnership with several local organizations that primarily serve an underprivileged population. Since the inception of our program in 2014, we have reached over 800 students.

Together with the other PIs in this grant, he organized the `Dimers: Combinatorics, Representation Theory and Physics’ Summer School and Conference at the City University of New York. These events brought together physicists and mathematicians, ranging from students to senior researchers, working on dimer model adjacent topics.
